lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can revise possessive adjectives and match them to the correct image.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write on board: “his / her / its.” Show a picture: “This is Emma’s crab.” Ask: “Whose crab is it?” → “It’s hers.”
stretchStrategies: Students write 2–3 sentences using possessives, then challenge a peer with a “Whose is it?” question, answered in full.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write complete sentences using possessive adjectives.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Sentence starters on board: “This is his ___.” “That is her ___.” Students complete 2 examples using SB images.
stretchStrategies: Students write 2–3 sentences using possessives, then challenge a peer with a “Whose is it?” question, answered in full.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can correctly pronounce words with the “-ar” and “-or” sounds.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Dictate short sentences: “The shark is far.” Students repeat and underline target sounds, then practise with a partner.
stretchStrategies: Students write 2–3 sentences using possessives, then challenge a peer with a “Whose is it?” question, answered in full.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Certain common holiday activities are less likely to overlap with those of Western kids (eating seafood at the beach, going on tours in large groups)
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
